newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy privatisations good for stock market - Consob.
newsitem.headline: Italy privatisations good for stock market - Consob.

text.p: Italy's privatisation process has so far had a positive effect on the development of the country's stock market, Enzo Berlanda, chairman of bourse regulator Consob, said in the supervisory body's annual report.

"The weight of the main companies privatised is considerable," Consob said. "Capitalisation at end-1996 is equal to some 23 percent of the total and overall share trading equals around 22 percent of total bourse capitalisation.
"The value of shares floated of companies privatised or being privatised is equal to 41.8 percent of the overall capitalisation of the same stocks," the report said.
Operations carried out via public and institutional offers between end-1993 and the end of 1996 were worth a total 27.28 trillion lire ($16.4 billion), Consob said.
In this period the Treasury sold off stakes worth over 24.50 trillion lire. At the same time, privately negotiated sales of quoted companies totalled 5.65 trillion lire.

In 1996, Consob noted that institutional investors had played a major role in privatisation share placements, with over 90 percent of operations carried out, including a private placement aimed at institutionals as well as a public offer.

Demand largely exceeded offers last year and the stock market was boosted by the listing of new companies "as also confirmed by the performance of such stocks which was well above that of the bourse index," Consob said.
